bibl.title: Tarjumān al-ashwāq
ترجمان الأشواق
bibl.incipit: Al-ḥamdu lillāh al-ḥusn al-faʿʿāl al-jamīl alladhī yuhibb al-jamāl… layta shiʿrī hal darū ayyā qalbin malakū
bibl.author: Ibn al-ʿArabī

noteGrp.note: 61 mystical love poems to the Divine Beauty, in the qaṣīda form of pre-Islamic poetry. According to Pablo Beneito (Qurrat al-ʿAyn, 2020), the original collection was 60 odes, to which were added first one then two poems in the preface. It was composed in 611H in Mecca, although the inspiration came in 604H in the meeting with Qurrat al-ʿAyn.

bibl.note: A much copied work, both on its own and with the commentary (RG116). There are no definitive historic mss. to verify the text in its own right, but there are several for the commentary, which includes the text of the poems. The best copies are therefore contained within mss. of Dhakhāʾir . The best stand-alone mss. are Manisa 6596 (undated, taken from SQ’s copy), and Ragib Pasha 1453 (although very late, probably also taken from SQ’s copy). There is an issue with the preface on this work. There are two basic variants; some mss carry the same preface as the commentary, Dhakhāʾir al-alāq (RG 116. Others have a longer version which begin with a khutba and IA’s account of meeting the young girl, Niẓam, who inspired the poems in Mecca. The situation is complex, with several other variants appearing in some mss (see Jane Clark Mystical Perception and Beauty: Ibn ʿArabī’s Preface to Tarjumān al-Ashwāq in JMIAS 55, 2013).

noteGrp.note: Reference to work in the Ijāza
Reference to work in the Fihrist
Referenes to work in other works

Critical Edition published by R A Nicholson and published alongside his English translation The Tarjumān al-ashwāq (London, 1911). However, the manuscripts he used were all late and had no special provenance.

Full English translation of the poems, but not the commentary, by R A Nicholson: The Tarjumān al-ashwāq, London, 1911. Full English translation by Michael Sells: The Translator of Desires, Princeton, 2021. Partial English translation by Michael Sells: Stations of Desire, Jerusalem, 2000. Translation of the Preface by Jane Clark available on http://www.ibnarabisociety.org/articlespdf/preface-tarjuman-al-ashwaq.pdf French translation of poems and commentary by Maurice Gloton, L’interprète des désirs, Paris, 1996. Partial French translation by Mahmoud Sami-Ali: Le chant de l'ardent désir, Arles 2006. Italian translation by Roberto Rossi Testa, L’interprete delle passioni, Milano, 2008
Spanish translation by Carlos Varona Narvión: El intérprete de los deseos, Murcia, 2002. Partial German translation by Alma Geise: Ibn ʿArabī: Urwolke und Welt, Munich 2002.
